addressleaf.section:
28 July
1589
To M
r
Bodleigh in answer to his of
e 26 of Junij & 9 Julij.

page.lettertext:
S
r
, Inanswere to yo
r
letters w
ch
I received,
e one
of
e 26 of
e last moneth,
e other of
e 9 of this instant
July, yo
w
shall understand
t
I doe not much marveyle
at
e sharpenes and hard bent of
Barnevelt
against her
M
tie
and this nation, and
e hott course he holdeth in all consultations
and actions touchinge them: for
t
in sondry of
e conferences of
e
LL
had w
th
e Deputies, there have bin hard speaches
lett fall of him, and of his harshe humors, w
ch
it may
be
e
Deputies
ether
advertised over ether in respect of good will,
t
some of them in particular doe beare him, or to sharpen
him more in his humor, thereby
e soner to make him to r
o
ne
him self out of breath, and to become odious amongest them.
And if I be not deceived, by some other
particuler
privat
advise
w
ch
I heare from thence, I conceive it will so fall out
in
e ende, and
t
before it be longe. for I am given to under-
stand,
t
his doinges are not greatly liked, or rather much mis-
liked, of
e best and most, and
t
he is very likely to weare
himself out of conceipt before it be longe, if he change not
e course of his humors. for it is reported,
t
he seketh to
draw a line,
t
is both unlikely ever to be broght to passe
by him, and
t
in it self c
a
not but tourne to
e ruine
rather of these contries, then any good.
As for
yo
r
direction for yo
r
self, there c
a
as yet be no better
given then yo
w
have alredy receaved, for
t
all certaintie
therein, will depend uppon such Conference, as by more
ample C
o
mission given to these Deputies, wilbe had w
th
them, or w
th
such
other, as they shall thinke good to send over.
W
ch
matter yo
w
shal doe wel
to
hasten, and so their LL. plea-
sure is yo
w
shold procure w
th
all instancie yo
w
c
a
, who like
very wel of yo
r
procedinge w
th
e states, accordinge to
e direction yo
w
formerly received from them in
t
be-
half. Amongest them yo
w
may not forgett to acknoledge
yo
r
self much bounde and beholdinge to my
L. Treasorer
,
who hath deliv
r
very good wordes to her M
tie
oft times of
yo
r
painefull travail and advised dealinge in
e charge co-mitted to yo
w
. Yo
w
shall doe well in
t
behalf
respect
to wright
oftener unto him, wherein as yo
w
shall
doe his L. satisfaction, so it
c
a
not but tourne yow to good.
fol.218v
Were it not
t
e matter of
sending
other C
o
missioners hither, or
more ample C
o
mission
rs
to these, had bin so farre
forth proceded in, as it is, both her M
tie
and
e
LL. coold have better liked to have had
e confer
e
ce
and metinge of C
o
missioners there, beinge of opinion
t
e Conference wold have bin w
th
more spede ended
there,
then it wilbe here. But seing it is so farre proce-
ded in, the course is not to be altered, but their dis-
patche to be hastened, w
ch
is eftsones rec
o
mended
to yo
r
charge and Care.
Their LL. were in a good way by conference w
th
e
Deputies to have taken some reasonable course for
e satisfaction of
e
L. Willughby
, w
ch
e said Depu-
ties had in part promised, but
e comminge forth of
his L. apologie brake of
e purpose.
This day we received newes out of
France,
of
e
murder of
e
K.
by a Jacopin, and
t
e Nobilitie
and Captaines of
e armie gave their othe to
e
K. of Navarre
to be loyall & trew unto him, and not
to forsake him, but to seke by all meanes the revenge
of
t
so horrible an outrage c
o
mitted uppon
e person
of
e K.
And so I leave yo
w
to God. From
e
Court at Nonesuch
e of July
1589
.
